post_text:
We trusted the key. The key failed us.
I still believe competence starts with recognizing doubt. I thought I knew exactly how my new transaction processor worked.

My initial design leveraged keyed events on a single partition. Event ordering, I declared, was guaranteed by Kafka itself 🤝.

A sudden surge of high-frequency trades hammered the system during market open.

Initial symptom reports filtered in: accounts showing negative balances immediately after a credit. Data integrity was shattered.

This shouldn’t happen. The key ensures ordering per user.

But the processing queue was showing deposits arriving after corresponding withdrawals, consistently. The contradiction was jarring.

My personal assumption was that the service guarantee inherently extended through the entire asynchronous pipeline. I was wrong.

Then I saw the consumer group logs: a partition rebalance initiated by a slow consumer. The re-read offset broke the strict sequence.

Kafka guarantees order within the partition, but group offsets can shift processing windows. We relied too heavily on infrastructure guarantees when the application needed atomic sequence checks.

The Moral 👇
Trust the wire, but validate the sequence stamp.
